G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 (district court civil jurisdiction).

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 2 because the property that is the subject of this action is located in Brockton, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, a landlord may not directly or indirectly interfere with the quiet enjoyment of a tenant’s leased premises.

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 717\.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly recognized the deprivation of essential utilities as a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 717\.support_reasoning: Blackett v. Olanoff does concern breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, but the breach found there was based on excessive noise and disturbances from a bar, not deprivation of essential utilities such as heat, water, or electricity. The opinion merely cites another case (Charles E. Burt) as an example of a quiet-enjoyment breach involving utilities, but Blackett itself does not address or reaffirm a utilities-based rule in any substantive way. Therefore, it does not itself stand as authority that Massachusetts courts have repeatedly recognized deprivation of essential utilities as a breach of quiet enjoyment.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 717\.relevant_excerpt: There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done. Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Corp., 340 Mass. 124, 127 (1959) (failure to supply light, heat, power, and elevator services).

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly recognized the deprivation of essential utilities as a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion extensively discusses interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and the common-law covenant, but the facts and analysis involve repeated flooding and unsanitary conditions, not deprivation of essential utilities such as heat, water, or electricity. The court does recognize that § 14 covers both failure to provide essential services and interference with quiet enjoyment, but it does not hold or discuss that deprivation of essential utilities constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Thus, it is not good authority for the specific utilities-based proposition cited.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.relevant_excerpt: “In relevant part, G. L. c. 186, § 14, as amended through St. 1974, c. 192, § 1, provides that: ‘Any lessor or landlord … who is required by law or by the express or implied terms of any contract or lease or tenancy at will to furnish water, hot water, heat, light, power, gas, elevator service, telephone service, janitor service or refrigeration service … who willfully or intentionally fails to furnish such … [services] … or any lessor or landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant … shall be [liable]….’”}

Winchester v. O'Brien, 266 Mass. 33 (192.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly recognized the deprivation of essential utilities as a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Winchester v. O'Brien, 266 Mass. 33 (192.support_reasoning: The case recognizes substantial interference with use and enjoyment (including interruptions of electric and water service) as actionable wrongful interference and potentially a breach of quiet enjoyment, but it does not specifically or repeatedly frame deprivation of essential utilities as a distinct, recognized category of breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The court analyzes a broader pattern of noise, dust, access issues, and some temporary utility interruptions, and treats them collectively as substantial interference/nuisance, not as a standalone utilities-based breach. Thus it is weak authority for the specific proposition that Massachusetts courts have repeatedly recognized deprivation of essential utilities as a breach of quiet enjoyment.
Winchester v. O'Brien, 266 Mass. 33 (192.relevant_excerpt: “Even though the work was carried on in a reasonable and proper manner and entirely outside the rooms leased, injury was done to the property and appliances used in those rooms; there were interruptions of the electric and water service therein, the plaintiff’s right of access was made more difficult, his property was injured, and he suffered a loss of income in business.… It is evident from the facts found that there has been a substantial and continued interference with the plaintiff’s beneficial enjoyment of the leased premises and appurtenant rights by the acts done or authorized by the defendants.”

Hemingway v. O\u2019Hara, 63 Mass. App..raw_text: Hemingway v. O’Hara, 63 Mass. App. Ct. 1 (2005)
Hemingway v. O\u2019Hara, 63 Mass. App..proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly recognized the deprivation of essential utilities as a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Hemingway v. O\u2019Hara, 63 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The provided opinion is a criminal case about the legality of a vehicle impoundment and inventory search, plus an ineffective-assistance claim. It does not concern landlord–tenant law, covenants of quiet enjoyment, or deprivation of utilities. Therefore it cannot be used as authority for the proposition that Massachusetts courts have recognized deprivation of essential utilities as a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Hemingway v. O\u2019Hara, 63 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: No passage in this opinion addresses landlord–tenant law, quiet enjoyment, or deprivation of utilities; the case discusses only search and seizure issues and ineffective assistance of counsel in a drug prosecution.

G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 8A.proposition: Defendant’s failure to ensure continuous hot water service constitutes a material and unreasonable interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment, in violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14 and G.L. c. 239, § 8A.

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: Defendant’s conduct also constitutes a violation of the implied warranty of habitability under Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973), as the absence of hot water renders the premises unfit for human habitation.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: The excerpt is from a concurring/dissenting opinion that criticizes the majority’s broader ‘implied warranty of habitability’ and argues instead for a warranty tied to code violations, but it does not itself state or apply a rule that the absence of hot water renders premises unfit for human habitation. Nor does this excerpt contain the majority’s operative language establishing the scope of the implied warranty. While Hemingway overall is the leading Massachusetts case recognizing an implied warranty of habitability, this particular text does not clearly support the specific hot‑water proposition cited.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “I dissent from the statement of such a broad and sweeping new rule for the reason, in part, that it would be sufficient for the decision of these cases to hold that the landlord, in renting the apartments to the tenants, impliedly agreed that the apartments would comply with the several requirements of the Code which the tenants allege were violated, and that if the tenants sustain their burden of proof of such violations their liability for the unpaid rent may be reduced to the fair value of their use and occupancy of the apartments in their deficient condition.”

Cunningham v. Davis, 91 Mass. App. Ct. 1.raw_text: Cunningham v. Davis, 91 Mass. App. Ct. 12 (2018)
Cunningham v. Davis, 91 Mass. App. Ct. 1.proposition: A landlord’s “good faith” or “effort” to obtain a repair part does not excuse delay that results in ongoing deprivation of an essential service.

Spence v. O'Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 489.raw_text: Spence v. O'Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 489 (1983)
Spence v. O'Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 489.proposition: The continuing lack of hot water amounts to a “continuing violation” under Spence v. O'Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 489 (1983), resulting in ongoing injury to Plaintiff’s tenancy rights.
Spence v. O'Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 489.support_reasoning: The opinion in Spence v. O'Brien concerns eviction for drug-related lease violations in public housing and related notice and procedural issues; it does not address habitability, lack of hot water, or any concept of a "continuing violation" tied to ongoing injury to tenancy rights. The only "continuing" concept discussed is the tenant’s ongoing knowledge of and tolerance for a third party’s misconduct, not a continuing conditions-based breach by the landlord. Therefore, it does not provide authority for treating lack of hot water as a continuing violation.
Spence v. O'Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 489.relevant_excerpt: "It must be remembered, however, that O’Brien is in breach of the terms and conditions of her lease by reason of her knowledge and tolerance of Harris’ conduct over a prolonged period of time. ‘The element of personal responsibility encompassed by § 32 also adds to the connection between eviction and legitimate government purposes. As construed, § 32 serves to encourage tenants to attempt to guide the conduct of household members, and to seek help when they are unable to.’ Spence v. Gormley, 387 Mass. at 273."

Westland Hous. Corp. v. Scott, 312 Mass..raw_text: Westland Hous. Corp. v. Scott, 312 Mass. 375 (1942)
Westland Hous. Corp. v. Scott, 312 Mass..proposition: Defendant’s failure to act within a reasonable time after notice constitutes a constructive eviction as well as a breach of the covenant, see Westland Hous. Corp. v. Scott, 312 Mass. 375 (1942); Dwelley v. Chesterfield, 386 Mass. 228, 236 (1982).
Westland Hous. Corp. v. Scott, 312 Mass..support_reasoning: The case squarely holds that the landlord’s failure, over a substantial period, to remedy conditions that deprived the tenant of use and enjoyment of the premises, despite notice and promises to fix them, constituted a constructive eviction and a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, excusing the tenant from further rent. While the opinion does not use the exact phrase “failure to act within a reasonable time after notice,” its reasoning rests on the landlord’s prolonged failure to correct the problem after it arose and was known, and on the tenant’s right to vacate within a reasonable time, which the court found he did. Thus, it substantively supports the proposition that such a failure can amount both to constructive eviction and breach of covenant.
Westland Hous. Corp. v. Scott, 312 Mass..relevant_excerpt: In all the circumstances we are of opinion that the landlord must be presumed to have intended the natural consequences of its own acts, subsequent to the installation of the oil burner, in failing to remedy the conditions which deprived the tenant of the use and enjoyment of the premises over a substantial period of time, and that the judge was warranted on the facts disclosed by the evidence in concluding that the tenant had been evicted by the landlord. ... The defence of eviction, actual or constructive, is based upon a failure of consideration, or a breach, whether of commission or omission, of a covenant of the lease so material as to excuse the tenant from performing.

Dwelley v. Chesterfield, 386 Mass. 228,.proposition: Defendant’s failure to act within a reasonable time after notice constitutes a constructive eviction as well as a breach of the covenant, see Westland Hous. Corp. v. Scott, 312 Mass. 375 (1942); Dwelley v. Chesterfield, 386 Mass. 228, 236 (1982).
Dwelley v. Chesterfield, 386 Mass. 228,.case_name: District Attorney for the Plymouth District v. Coffey
Dwelley v. Chesterfield, 386 Mass. 228,.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns criminal procedure and constitutional/wiretap issues arising from telephone tracing and has nothing to do with landlord-tenant law, constructive eviction, or covenants. It does not mention reasonable time to act after notice, breaches of covenants, or constructive eviction, so it cannot support the stated proposition. The citation to Dwelley v. Chesterfield for that landlord-tenant principle is therefore inaccurate in the context of this text.
Dwelley v. Chesterfield, 386 Mass. 228,.relevant_excerpt: The defendant was charged with three violations of G. L. c. 269, § 14A. The complaints alleged that he used the telephone repeatedly for the sole purpose of harassing, annoying, or molesting Elaine Coffey, his former wife. A judge of a District Court, after a hearing, allowed the defendant’s motion to suppress “Any portions of the contents of any interception or any evidence derived therefrom as a result of the use of a pen register or similar device….” … We reverse the order allowing the motion to suppress.
